Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Ciliate Genomics Consortium Model for Sustainable Teaching-Research Integration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engaging more undergraduates in research experiences is a priority for improving science education and course-based research experiences are a promising approach to reaching larger numbers of students. The Ciliate Genomics Consortium (CGC) is a student-centered, nation-wide collaborative learning community that uses scalable functional genomics research for integration into courses in a variety of biology sub-disciplines. The CGC employs an integrative teaching and research model that combines both inquiry-driven class laboratory activities and collaborative consortium pedagogies to advance faculty research. Previously, the CGC developed modular course-based research curricula that, when adopted by the research community using the ciliate Tetrahymena, effectively engaged greater numbers of students in authentic research while advancing faculty research. This work expands the consortium by creating new or improving tested curricula to promote their broad adoption, creating more opportunities for teaching/research integration. If successful, this project provide evidence that students in classroom settings can contribute substantially to faculty and community research priorities with a variety of model organisms.

To achieve project goals, the CGC will: 1) develop curricula adaptable to faculty research interests, integrate consortium activities with research community resources, and assess student learning gains; and 2) disseminate the CGC model through training workshops and assess the impact on faculty teaching and student learning. Curricula are disseminated through annual workshops and test whether research communities can foster learning communities that promote faculty adoption of classroom-based research as a high impact teaching practice. In this model, members of a research community form a professional learning community to enhance and apply best STEM teaching practices. To learn more about the effectiveness of this approach for both students and educators, the project will assess the pedagogy and report any conceptual gains this research-based curriculum offers over other instructional models, and present limitations and challenges observed. Several validated instruments will be used to measure confidence and learning gains with newly developed assessments to evaluate predicted cognitive gains. Cohorts of students at each institution are identified, not engaged in the CGC curriculum, to control for instructor and institutional factors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project is to disseminate curriculum enabling faculty to engage students in authentic research in the classroom and to assess whether integration of faculty research and teaching can be an effective means to both increase student learning and motivate professors to adopt best teaching practice. Specific ways this was accomplished was through providing faculty/student training in the form of summer workshops that gave hands on examples of modules to integrate research into the classroom labs.  Student TAs were awarded to support implementation of research experiences in college courses.  The research modules have been disseminated at these workshops as well as a Methods section has been created on SUPRdb.org to populate the modules for easier access. Faculty from the consortium at seventeen institutions either developed new course-based research curriculum or utilized/adapted our existing curricula to engage over 650 students in inquiry or full research experiences as part of their regular course teaching. We've had success reaching more students due to module adoption in larger Intro Biology courses at a range of institutions.  The workshops that have been conducted have fostered the creation of new consortiums and modules in Drosophila to incorporate research in the classroom and attendees from Giardia, Hydra, and Dictyostelium have started to work on creating modules for their research model organism to incorporate into classroom labs.    

Techniques and products developed under this award have promoted adoption of best teaching practices through facilitating integration of faculty teaching and research interests. Through an expanding consortium of teacher-scholars, we've trained an additional thirteen faculty in implementation of course-based research, facilitated their identification with a vibrant, supportive, and collaborative teaching/research community, and assisted in customizing existing course research curricula to meet their own teaching goals. We've directly assisted an entire biology department in adopting inquiry modules into their introductory biology curriculum.  Two websites have been developed over the course of the project.  Over the last couple of years, our consortium has experienced a rate of growth that is faster than expected, and much of this is driven by faculty and laboratory staff who have no experience using the Tetrahymena model. Instead of beginning their own consortiums, faculty who do research with other model organisms are opting to work with Tetrahymena in their courses instead of developing similar modules with their research system. SUPRDB.org is a self-publication site that collects and displays unpublished reports from researchers (primarily students).  SUPRDB has been specifically designed to interface with genome databases, and to encourage users to provide information, such as gene names and Gene Ontology annotations, useful for curating gene annotations.  A separate Ciliate Genomics Consortium (CGC) website has been developed to allow sharing of lab modules and administrative documents among instructors. Instead of encouraging teacher-scholars using other model organisms to develop their own consortiums in isolation, we will try to modify our existing infrastructure such as databases for sharing results, listserves, and workshops so as to allow other communities to use these existing resources to get started. This change in approach is due to increased awareness about the barriers to initiating collaborative groups, especially amongst junior faculty who are often the most interested.  We have now successfully employed this strategy to support formation of the new Drosophila consortium, who will continue to collaborate with CGC for faculty development, module development, research support, and dissemination of student-generated results.  There has been over 80 undergraduates that have been able to present their research at local, regional, and National/International conferences over the length of this project.  Over the course of this project the activities have created a supportive network of committed faculty united by common education goals and broader scholarship goals, to help sustain the implementation of student-centered, course-based research in the classroom.
